content.question: Water in a river flows uniformly to the east with a speed of <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the shore. A boat is traveling to the west at <math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the water. A passenger on the boat is walking at <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> to the east, toward the back of the boat. Which of the following statements about the passengerâ€™s velocity is correct and gives the correct reason?

choices.label: The passenger is moving at <math alttext="20 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the shore because the boat is moving at <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the shore and the passenger is moving at <math alttext="15 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the water.

The passenger is moving at <math alttext="20 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the shore because the sum of all of the velocities (<math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>, <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>) is <math alttext="20 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>.

The passenger is stationary relative to the shore because the boat is moving at <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the shore and the passenger is moving at <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the boat in the opposite direction.

The passenger is stationary relative to the shore because the boat is moving at <math alttext="15 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the water and the passenger is moving at <math alttext="15 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> in the opposite direction relative to the water.

content.answer: The passenger is stationary relative to the shore because the boat is moving at <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the shore and the passenger is moving at <math alttext="5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> relative to the boat in the opposite direction.
